Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Optimizing Multibeam Data Acquisition Operations and Quality for the U.S. Academic Research Fleet
Award.AbstractNarration:
This collaborative effort proposes to establish technical resources and new communication mechanisms to develop and share common information, tools, and expertise regarding the operation and monitoring of multibeam sonars across the U.S. Academic Fleet. The strategy is to create a community of stakeholders including representatives from each operating institution, complemented by key outside experts from the user and technical/engineering communities that can assist in providing guidance on a broad array of multibeam issues to improve how these data are collected and assessed. In addition, the effort proposes to establish a Multibeam Advisory Committee (MAC) that will act as an overall coordinating body with the primary goal of supporting mapping operations onboard vessels in the U.S. academic research fleet and ensuring that high quality data are consistently acquired. They will also assemble small groups of individuals from the MAC and community of stakeholders into technical teams, each of which is tasked with specific components of multibeam system performance evaluation.

Broader Impacts
The principal impact of the present proposal is under criterion two, providing infrastructure support for scientists to use the vessel and its shared-use instrumentation in support of their NSF-funded oceanographic research projects (which individually undergo separate review by the relevant research program of NSF). The support of maintenance and operation of shared-use instrumentation allows NSF-funded researchers from any US university or lab access to working, calibrated instruments for their research, reducing the cost of that research, and expanding the base of potential researchers. All users (or the appropriate funding agencies) share support for basic pooled services on the vessel equally, with NSF paying a share of the support costs based on fractional usage of the vessel during the year.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Our understanding of Earth’s oceans depends on building basic knowledge of the shape of the seafloor, from the deepest depths of the Mariana Trench to the shallowest reefs and volcanic islands.  The seafloor morphology impacts natural ocean processes such as currents, indicates distribution of resources such as fisheries and minerals, and has implications for maritime shipping and boundaries.  While satellite data provides low-resolution regional maps of the seafloor, high-resolution data are best collected using modern sonar mapping systems mounted on oceanographic research vessels.  These sonar systems (called ‘multibeam echosounders’) produce a wide swath of depth data across the seafloor along the ship track, providing a broader and more accurate representation of the seafloor than other techniques (Fig. 1).

Naturally, these seafloor mapping systems require high-precision GPS positioning and vessel motion sensors to correctly measure depths.  Changes in sound speed throughout the world’s oceans also have a major effect on multibeam echosounder data, causing refraction artifacts if not properly corrected.  Integrating all of the required sensors and data streams (Fig. 2), and optimizing acquisition parameters to provide the most efficient and effective sonar coverage presents many challenges to the technicians and scientists on board.  Complications during data acquisition also make the datasets more difficult to use by scientists and the public, reducing the return on investment in these mapping expeditions.

In 2010, the National Science Foundation (NSF) conducted a workshop which identified the need to coordinate operational efforts in order to improve multibeam sonar data quality among U.S. academic research vessels.  Shortly thereafter, in 2011, the Multibeam Advisory Committee (MAC) was established under NSF grant 1150574 to identify and address technical issues in the setup and operation of these mapping systems, improve data quality and utility for all stakeholders, and coordinate the implementation of solutions across the U.S. academic research fleet.

The MAC was involved during the initial testing, calibration, and acceptance for each new multibeam mapping system installed over the last four years (Figs. 3, 4).  Considering the high cost of these systems and their operation, these initial tests are critical for characterizing the baseline performance and ensuring the best possible data quality from the start of the sonar life cycle.  For instance, during visits to the U.S. academic research vessels, the MAC planned and executed a series of tests to evaluate the accuracy, swath coverage, and hardware health for each ship’s sonar systems.

These tests provided scientists both on board and at large with useful guidelines for their mapping programs, leading to more efficient expedition planning.  When vessels made modifications to their mapping systems or suspected degraded performance for some reason, the MAC used baseline data from across the fleet to verify satisfactory performance and/or to provide context for troubleshooting.

MAC support was provided in person in the shipyard, on board at sea, and remotely via email or satellite phone.  Ship visits were scheduled to minimize impact on existing science expeditions, saving costly ship time by taking advantage of transits and other equipment trials to evaluate multibeam sonar performance and working with operators to improve the data acquisition and processing workflows.  Software tools and best practices developed by the MAC were shared among the vessels, resulting in improved data quality and driving an increase in demand for these services throughout the grant period.
